*Subject: CHRISTIANS as SAINTS *(read Col. 1:5-13)



*Verse for Today:*

*Giving thanks to the Father, who has qualified you to*

* share in the inheritance of the saints in the kingdom *

*of light. *(Col. 1:12)



*Food for Thought:*

*Christians: *even before they enter the kingdom of light

in heaven, are people who let the light of the Gospel

shine through in their lives. In all they say and do—and

in all the evil things they leave undone—they give

evidence of their commitment to God, the Father of

lights. How do people become *saints *who let the light

shine through? It begins when the Holy Spirit enlightens

them through the Gospel and Holy Baptism, bring them

to faith in Jesus Christ, as their Savior. To declare

Christian as bona fide *saints* is *not* to say that they are

perfect. They are sinners still because of their continuing

spiritual weakness. *But sin does not rule their lives;*

*Jesus Christ does. *

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
Christians: even before they enter the kingdom of light in
heaven, are people who let the light of the Gospel shine
through in their lives. In all they say and do-and in all
the evil things they leave undone-they give evidence of
their commitment to God, the Father of lights. How do people
become saints who let the light shine through? It begins
when the Holy Spirit enlightens them through the Gospel and
Holy Baptism, bring them to faith in Jesus Christ, as their
Savior. To declare Christian as bona fide saints is not to
say that they are perfect. They are sinners still because of
their continuing spiritual weakness. But sin does not rule
their lives; Jesus Christ does.
original_verse_text:
Giving thanks to the Father, who has qualified you to share
in the inheritance of the saints in the kingdom of light.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we give thanks to You for calling us out of darkness and into Your marvelous light. Through the power of Your Holy Spirit, may we walk worthy of Your kingdom, bearing fruit in every good work and growing in the knowledge of You. Strengthen us to endure with patience and joy, that we may joyfully give thanks to You, the Father who has qualified us to share in the inheritance of the saints in light. Amen.
reflection: Christians: even before they enter the kingdom of light in heaven, are people who let the light of the Gospel shine through in their lives. In all they say and do-and in all the evil things they leave undone-they give evidence of their commitment to God, the Father of lights. How do people become saints who let the light shine through? It begins when the Holy Spirit enlightens them through the Gospel and Holy Baptism, bring them to faith in Jesus Christ, as their Savior. To declare Christian as bona fide saints is not to say that they are perfect. They are sinners still because of their continuing spiritual weakness. But sin does not rule their lives; Jesus Christ does.
subject: Christians as Saints
verse_text:
Giving thanks to the Father, who has qualified you to share
in the inheritance of the saints in the kingdom of light.

*Today’s Verse:*

*“come, follow Me,” Jesus said, “and I will make you*

*fishers of men.” *(Mk. 1:17)



*Food for Thought:*

The fish symbol ICHTHYS is an abbreviation confession

of faith—shorthand for the Greek *Isus Christos Theou*

*Hyios Soter**: * Jesus Christ, Son of God, Savior.

The fish symbol is fitting because Jesus drew His first

disciples from fishermen, from two sets of brothers:

Peter and Andrew and James and John. Of course we

know, fish were used in some of His miracles.

As called and commissioned apostles, Peter and the

others went into the world as fishers of people to let

down the net of the Gospel, and they were effective.

“The disciples went out and preached everywhere,

and the Lord worked with them and confirmed His

Word by the signs that accompanied it” (Mk 16:20).

The ICHTHYS symbol is a reminder that Jesus Christ

is our Savior calling us to be fishers of people and

*“to give an answer to everyone who asks you to*

*give the reason for the hope you have” *(I Pet. 3:15).

*Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
The fish symbol ICHTHYS is an abbreviation confession of
faith-shorthand for the Greek Isus Christos Theou Hyios
Soter: Jesus Christ, Son of God, Savior. The fish symbol is
fitting because Jesus drew His first disciples from
fishermen, from two sets of brothers: Peter and Andrew and
James and John. Of course we know, fish were used in some of
His miracles. As called and commissioned apostles, Peter and
the others went into the world as fishers of people to let
down the net of the Gospel, and they were effective. “The
disciples went out and preached everywhere, and the Lord
worked with them and confirmed His Word by the signs that
accompanied it” (Mark 16:20). The ICHTHYS symbol is a reminder
that Jesus Christ is our Savior calling us to be fishers of
people and “to give an answer to everyone who asks you to
give the reason for the hope you have” (I Peter 3:15).
original_verse_text: "Come, follow Me," Jesus said, "and I will make you fishers of men."
prayer: Heavenly Father, we give thanks that You have called us, like the first disciples, to be fishers of people. Help us to follow the example of Peter, Andrew, James, and John, who left their nets to follow Jesus and become witnesses of Your saving grace. May the ICHTHYS symbol remind us of our confession of faith in Christ, the Son of God and our Savior, who works with us and confirms Your Word through the power of the Holy Spirit. Grant us courage and wisdom to cast the net of the Gospel and draw others to the hope we have in You. Amen.
reflection: The fish symbol ICHTHYS is an abbreviation confession of faith-shorthand for the Greek Isus Christos Theou Hyios Soter: Jesus Christ, Son of God, Savior. The fish symbol is fitting because Jesus drew His first disciples from fishermen, from two sets of brothers: Peter and Andrew and James and John. *Verse for Today:*

Jesus said: *“When you see a cloud rising in the west,*

*immediately you say, ‘it’s going to rain,’ and it does.”*

(Lk. 12:54)



*How Good Are We At Interpreting Signs?*

For most of recorded history, the world’s principal

occupation was farming. The farmer depended

directly on the weather for his livelihood. He needed

just the right amount of sunshine and rain, to make

his living, and he grew skilled at interpreting natural

signs. Jesus was announcing an earthshaking event

that would be much more important than the year’s

crops—the coming of God’s Kingdom. Just as dark

clouds forewarned of a rainstorm, there were signs

that the Kingdom would soon arrive. But Jesus’

hearer’s though skilled at interpreting weather signs,

were intentionally ignoring the signs of the times.

*Pastor Al*

be much more important than the year’s crops-the coming of
God’s Kingdom. Just as dark clouds forewarned of a
rainstorm, there were signs that the Kingdom would soon
arrive. But Jesus’ hearer’s though skilled at interpreting
weather signs, were intentionally ignoring the signs of the
times.
original_verse_text: Jesus said: “When you see a cloud rising in the west, immediately you say, ‘it’s going to rain,’ and it does.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You, humbled by the example of the farmers who were skilled at interpreting the signs of nature. Yet, we confess that we often fail to discern the signs of Your Kingdom's arrival, even as it draws near. Open our eyes, Lord, to recognize the profound and life-changing work You are doing in our midst. Help us to be attentive to the signs of Your coming, that we may be prepared to welcome Your Kingdom and walk in obedience to Your will. We ask this in the name of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Simon Peter answered, “You are the Christ, the Son*

*of the living God.” *(Mt. 16:16)



*Some food for Thought:*

The apostle Peter was inconsistent in his relationship

to Jesus. He was impetuous, restless, and unstable. His

worst moment came, *when he denied knowing Jesus*

*despite his boast:* “Even if I have to die with You, I

will never disown You” (Mk. 14:31). *But* Peter was

also a rock, firm and solid. When Jesus asked His

disciples after hearing what others thought of Him

“Who do you say I am?” Peter answered. “You are

the Christ, the Son of the living God.” On that point

Peter never wavered.

How can we become rock-solid in our faith? *. . . *The

Word of God and His means of grace will strengthen

our faith in Christ and make us into “a pillar in the

temple of my God” (Rev. 3:12).

*Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
The apostle Peter was inconsistent in his relationship to
Jesus. He was impetuous, restless, and unstable. His worst
moment came, when he denied knowing Jesus despite his boast:
“Even if I have to die with You, I will never disown You”
(Mark 14:31). But Peter was also a rock, firm and solid. When
Jesus asked His disciples after hearing what others thought
of Him “Who do you say I am?” Peter answered. “You are the
Christ, the Son of the living God.” On that point Peter
never wavered. How can we become rock-solid in our faith? .
. . The Word of God and His means of grace will strengthen
our faith in Christ and make us into “a pillar in the temple
of my God” (Revelation 3:12).
original_verse_text: Simon Peter answered, "You are the Christ, the Son of the living God."
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, seeking to grow in our faith and devotion to You. Like the apostle Peter, we confess that our relationship with You can be inconsistent and unstable. Yet, we desire to be rock-solid in our declaration that Jesus is the Christ, the Son of the living God. Lord, strengthen our faith through Your Word and Your means of grace, that we may become pillars in Your temple, firmly grounded in the truth of Your Son. May our lives reflect the unwavering commitment to follow and serve You. Amen.
reflection: The apostle Peter was inconsistent in his relationship to Jesus. He was impetuous, restless, and unstable. His worst moment came, when he denied knowing Jesus despite his boast: “Even if I have to die with You, I will never disown You” (Mark 14:31). But Peter was also a rock, firm and solid. When Jesus asked His disciples after hearing what others thought of Him “Who do you say I am?” Peter answered. “You are the Christ, the Son of the living God.” On that point Peter never wavered. How can we become rock-solid in our faith? . . . The Word of God and His means of grace will strengthen our faith in Christ and make us into “a pillar in the temple of my God” (Revelation 3:12).

*Verse for Today:*

*I will thank the Lord because He is just: I will sing *

*praises to the name of the Lord Most High. *(Ps. 7:17)



*Give This Verse Some Thought:*

During a time of great evil and injustice, (sounds a

little like now doesn’t it?): David was grateful that

God is just and fair. I imagine we have all wondered

how many honest people there are left in the world,

*but* we can be assured *and* thankful that God will

continue to bring justice and fairness when we involve

Him in our activities. If you ever feel you are being

treated unfairly, ask the One who is always fair and

just to be with you. *Then thank Him for His presence.*

(read Isa. 42:1-6)


This month is going to be about all the things we should

give thanks for.

*Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
During a time of great evil and injustice, (sounds a little
like now doesn’t it?): David was grateful that God is just
and fair. I imagine we have all wondered how many honest
people there are left in the world, but we can be assured
and thankful that God will continue to bring justice and
fairness when we involve Him in our activities. If you ever
feel you are being treated unfairly, ask the One who is
always fair and just to be with you. Then thank Him for His
presence. (read Isaiah 42:1-6)
original_verse_text:
I will thank the Lord because He is just: I will sing
praises to the name of the Lord Most High.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come to You in a time of great evil and injustice, just as Your servant David did. We are grateful that You are a God of justice and fairness, and we trust that You will continue to bring Your righteousness to light, even when the world seems dark. When we feel treated unfairly, we ask that You would be with us, guiding us and sustaining us. We thank You for Your constant presence and for Your unwavering commitment to justice. Amen.
reflection: During a time of great evil and injustice (sounds a little like now, doesn't it?), David was grateful that God is just and fair. I imagine we have all wondered how many honest people there are left in the world, but we can be assured and thankful that God will continue to bring justice and fairness when we involve Him in our activities. If you ever feel you are being treated unfairly, ask the One who is always fair and just to be with you. Then thank Him for His presence. (Read Isaiah 42:1-6)
subject: Thankfulness Our First Priority

*Today’s Verse:*

*Sing a song of thanksgiving and tell of all your*

*miracles. *(Ps. 26:7)



*Some Food for Thought:*

I don’t like to complain, *but* too often we complain

about our problems to anyone who will listen and

praise God only in private. How much better it would

be for us if we complained in private and praised

God in public. *Let us remember, to not only make this *

*month but every month a time of thankfulness as*

*our first priority.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
I don’t like to complain, but too often we complain about
our problems to anyone who will listen and praise God only
in private. How much better it would be for us if we
complained in private and praised God in public. Let us
remember, to not only make this month but every month a time
of thankfulness as our first priority.
original_verse_text: Sing a song of thanksgiving and tell of all your miracles.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, acknowledging that our tendency is to voice our complaints openly while reserving our praise for You in private. Forgive us for this misplaced priority. Help us to follow the example of the psalmist, who delighted in proclaiming Your steadfast love and faithfulness publicly. May our lives be a testament to Your goodness, that we may "tell of all Your wondrous works" and give You the honor and glory You deserve. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: I don't like to complain, but too often we complain about our problems to anyone who will listen and praise God only in private. How much better it would be for us if we complained in private and praised God in public. Let us remember to not only make this month but every month a time of thankfulness as our first priority.
subject: Thankfulness Our First Priority
verse_text: Sing a song of thanksgiving and tell of all your miracles.

*Verse for Today:*

*Help me O Lord, that I might sing praises to*

*You and not be slight. O Lord my God, I will*

*Give you thanks forever. *(Ps. 30:10c-12)



*Food for Thought:*

Sometimes our security makes us feel invincible.

The problem is we forget that all things come from

God. Let us not become trapped by a false security

that can be shattered. *Let us put our dependence*

*in God, giving Him thanks for all He provides.*

* Pastor Al *
original_reflection_text:
Sometimes our security makes us feel invincible. The problem
is we forget that all things come from God. Let us not
become trapped by a false security that can be shattered.
Let us put our dependence in God, giving Him thanks for all
He provides.
original_verse_text: You have turned my mourning into joyful dancing. You have taken off my clothes of mourning and clothed me with joy, that I might sing praises to you and not be silent. O Lord my God, I will give you thanks forever.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with humble hearts, acknowledging that our security and strength come from You alone. Forgive us for the times we have forgotten that all good things flow from Your gracious hand. Help us to trust in You, the source of our joy and the one who turns our mourning into dancing. May our lips be filled with praise, and our lives be a testament to Your faithfulness. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Sometimes our security makes us feel invincible. The problem is we forget that all things come from God. Let us not become trapped by a false security that can be shattered. Let us put our dependence in God, giving Him thanks for all He provides.

*Today’s Verse:*

*The one who offers thanksgiving as his sacrifice*

*glorifies Me; the one who orders his way rightly*

*I will show the salvation of God. *(Ps. 50:23)



*Food for Thought:*

God is not deaf, dumb, or blind to wickedness.

He patiently awaits our response. There are

some Bible translators who say: “*orders his way,”*

as referring to (*showing the fruit of faith*.) The

end result is that, there is nothing which the

citizens of heaven more love to look upon; and

there is nothing more agreeable to the eyes of

our Heavenly Father. *How does our Heavenly*

*Father judge your faith?*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse: *

*Let us come into His presence with thanksgiving;*

*let us make a joyful noise to Him with songs of*

*praise. *(Ps. 95:2)



*Food for Thought:*

If we are totally honest I believe we would all have

to say, we struggle to come into God’s presence

with the excitement and humility that is spoken of

in Psalm 95. *But *thankfully the palmist directs us

to not self-generate emotions *but* to remember the

God we worship. He is our Creator, who has formed

and protected us by his strong hands. *And* much

more—He is our Good Shepherd, who has made us

the sheep of His loving hands. *Dear Lord lead us into*

*your presence with thanksgiving and joy.*

*Pastor Al*

Subject*: HAVING AN ATTITUDE OF THANKS AND PRAISE *

(read Ps. 100)



*Verse for Today:*

*Enter His gates with thanksgiving, and His courts*

*with praise! Give thanks to Him; bless His name.*

(Ps. 100:4)



*Thoughts of How it Once Was:*

“*Enter His gates with thanksgiving, and His courts*

*with praise.”* (this to me is even speaking of the

church today) The emphasis is that this is God’s

place. I remember my mother talking about her

dad, how he would make all her brothers remove

their caps when they entered through the gates of

the church yard; because it was God’s holy place.

How unfortunate it is that we have lost this respect

for God’s property, and often for God Himself. Let

this be our prayer: “*Fill us with joyful praise and *

*thanksgiving as we seek to serve you!”*

* Pastor Al*

seek to serve you!"

Enter His gates with thanksgiving, and His courts with
praise! Give thanks to Him; bless His name.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, filled with joyful praise and thanksgiving. As we enter Your gates and courts, may we be mindful of the holiness of Your dwelling place. Help us to approach You with reverence and respect, remembering that this is Your holy ground. Fill us with a spirit of worship, that we may offer You the sacrifice of praise, glorifying Your name and seeking to serve You faithfully. In Your name, we pray. Amen.

*Today’s Verses*

*The Lord spoke, “I have made you a light for the*

*Gentiles, that you may bring salvation to the ends*

*of the earth.”—and when the Gentiles heard this*

*they began rejoicing and glorifying the Word of*

*the Lord. *(Acts 13:47, 48a)



*Food for Thought:*

An outreach to the Gentiles is not unique to the

N.T. we also see it in Isa. 49:6 and many other O.T.

passages. Although God chose us “before the

foundation of the world” (Eph. 1:4), His choice

was not arbitrary. He chose us to be save by

Christ and in union with Christ, who Himself is

God’s “Chosen One” (Lk. 9:35). *Thank God that *

*He chose us in Love, not anger or judgement.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
An outreach to the Gentiles is not unique to the N.T. we
also see it in Isaiah 49:6 and many other O.T. passages.
Although God chose us “before the foundation of the world”
(Ephesians 1:4), His choice was not arbitrary. He chose us to be
save by Christ and in union with Christ, who Himself is
God’s “Chosen One” (Luke 9:35). Thank God that He chose us in
Love, not anger or judgment.
original_verse_text: For this is what the Lord has commanded us: 'I have made you a light for the Gentiles, that you may bring salvation to the ends of the earth.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we give thanks that Your plan of salvation extends to all people, not just the nation of Israel. You have chosen us, not by our own merit, but in Your boundless love and grace, to be united with Your Chosen One, Jesus Christ. May we faithfully proclaim the good news of Your redemption to the ends of the earth, that all may come to know You and be saved. In the name of our Lord Jesus, we pray. Amen.
reflection: An outreach to the Gentiles is not unique to the N.T. We also see it in Isaiah 49:6 and many other O.T. passages. Although God chose us "before the foundation of the world" (Ephesians 1:4), His choice was not arbitrary. *Today’s Verse:*

*First, I thank my God for through Jesus Christ*

*for all of you, because your faith is proclaimed*

*In all the world. *(Ro. 1:8)



*Food for Thought:*

Paul was sent to the Greeks and barbarians, to

the wise and the foolish. Today, we may be

tempted to keep the Gospel to ourselves or

limit it to people like us. But Jesus did not limit

His work. He redeemed the whole world—even

Barbarians and fools like us. He has commissioned

us to reach out to all people. *So let us remember*

*to thank our Heavenly Father for trusting us to *

*be His witnesses.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
Paul was sent to the Greeks and barbarians, to the wise and
the foolish. Today, we may be tempted to keep the Gospel to
ourselves or limit it to people like us. But Jesus did not
limit His work. He redeemed the whole world-even Barbarians
and fools like us. He has commissioned us to reach out to
all people. So let us remember to thank our Heavenly Father
for trusting us to be His witnesses.
original_verse_text:
First, I thank my God for through Jesus Christ for all of
you, because your faith is proclaimed In all the world.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank You for the gift of the Gospel and the commission to share it with all people. Forgive us for the times we have been tempted to limit Your message to those who are familiar or similar to us. Help us to have the same heart as the Apostle Paul, who was willing to go to the Greeks and the barbarians, the wise and the foolish, for the sake of proclaiming Your redeeming love. May we be faithful witnesses, sharing the Good News with all who need to hear it. Amen.
reflection: Paul was sent to the Greeks and barbarians, to the wise and the foolish. Today, we may be tempted to keep the Gospel to ourselves or limit it to people like us. But Jesus did not limit His work. He redeemed the whole world—even barbarians and fools like us. He has commissioned us to reach out to all people. So let us remember to thank our Heavenly Father for trusting us to be His witnesses.

subject   : Subject: THANKS FOR HIS INEXPRESSIBLE GIFT (read II Cor. 9:11-15)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

*Today’s Verse:*

*You will be enriched in every way to be generous*

*In every way, which through us will produce *

*Thanksgiving to God. *(II Cor. 9:11)



*Food for Thought:*

Paul urges the Corinthians to go with the flow of God’s

self-giving in Christ by giving themselves to others, so

that the downward and outward movement of grace

comes full circle in the free flow of thanksgiving. Seeing

things in an earthly, me-first way is miserly and petty.

Instead, we should open our hands and heats to receive

God and extend them to give our neighbor.

*Let us be generous in every way that others will give*

*thanks to God for us.*

*Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
Paul urges the Corinthians to go with the flow of God’s
self-giving in Christ by giving themselves to others, so
that the downward and outward movement of grace comes full
circle in the free flow of thanksgiving. Seeing things in an
earthly, me-first way is miserly and petty. Instead, we
should open our hands and heats to receive God and extend
them to give our neighbor. Let us be generous in every way
that others will give thanks to God for us.
original_verse_text:
You will be enriched in every way to be generous In every
way, which through us will produce Thanksgiving to God.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we give thanks to You for the abundance of Your grace and the generosity You have shown us in Christ. May our hearts be opened to receive Your blessings, that we may in turn be generous and give freely to those around us. Help us to see beyond our own needs and to extend Your love and compassion to our neighbors, that they may give thanks to You through our actions. We pray that the flow of Your grace may come full circle, as we reflect Your self-giving nature in our lives. Amen.
reflection: Paul urges the Corinthians to go with the flow of God's self-giving in Christ by giving themselves to others, so that the downward and outward movement of grace comes full circle in the free flow of thanksgiving. Seeing things in an earthly, me-first way is miserly and petty. Instead, we should open our hands and hearts to receive God and extend them to give to our neighbor. Let us be generous in every way so that others will give thanks to God for us.
subject: Thanks for His Inexpressible Gift
verse_text:
You will be enriched in every way to be generous In every
way, which through us will produce Thanksgiving to God.

*Today’s Verse:*

*The Lord is at hand; do not be anxious about*

*anything, but in everything by prayer and *

*supplication with thanksgiving let your *

*requests be made known to God. *(Phil. 4:5b-6)



*Thoughts for Today:*

Paul urges us to adopt practices of living that

are in harmony with the Creator’s will. The

strength and clarity of this exhortation

reminds us that we often set our minds on

those things that are contrary to God’s will.

Paul’s exhortations are always followed by

promises of God’s blessings on our behalf.

*So remember that, a prayer with-out *

*thanksgiving is an unfinished prayer.*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
Paul urges us to adopt practices of living that are in
harmony with the Creator’s will. The strength and clarity of
this exhortation reminds us that we often set our minds on
those things that are contrary to God’s will. Paul’s
exhortations are always followed by promises of God’s
blessings on our behalf. So remember that, a prayer without
thanksgiving is an unfinished prayer.
original_verse_text:
The Lord is at hand; do not be anxious about anything, but
in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving
let your requests be made known to God.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, acknowledging the wisdom of Your ways and the peace that comes from aligning our lives with Your will. Help us to set our minds on what is true, noble, right, pure, lovely, and admirable, as Your servant Paul has instructed. May we be gentle in our interactions, rejoicing in the Lord always, and finding rest in the assurance of Your presence. We give thanks for Your bountiful blessings and the promise of Your peace that surpasses all understanding. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Paul urges us to adopt practices of living that are in harmony with the Creator's will. The strength and clarity of this exhortation reminds us that we often set our minds on those things that are contrary to God's will. Paul's exhortations are always followed by promises of God's blessings on our behalf. So remember that a prayer without thanksgiving is an unfinished prayer.

in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving
let your requests be made known to God.

*Verse for 11-18-2019*

*Whatever you do, in word or deed, do everything in *

*the name of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the*

*Father through Him. *(Col. 3:17)



*Thoughts for Today:*

The question that is often asked, “what is the good

Life?” ‘is it prosperity, popularity, pleasure?” *NO*

it is the life we receive from Jesus, including gifts

that we cannot make or purchase: forgiveness,

love, peace, and *thankfulness*. Jesus’ life fills us with

virtues rather than vices and enables us to be a blessing

rather than a ruin to others. *Before the dawning of *

*the final day let sin’s dark deeds be gone!*

* Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
The question that is often asked, “what is the good Life?”
‘is it prosperity, popularity, pleasure?” NO it is the life
we receive from Jesus, including gifts that we cannot make
or purchase: forgiveness, love, peace, and thankfulness.
Jesus’ life fills us with virtues rather than vices and
enables us to be a blessing rather than a ruin to others.
Before the dawning of the final day let sin’s dark deeds be
gone!
original_verse_text:
Whatever you do, in word or deed, do everything in the name
of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the Father through
Him.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we give thanks for the abundant life found in Your Son, Jesus Christ. May we clothe ourselves with the virtues of compassion, kindness, humility, gentleness, and patience, forgiving one another as You have forgiven us. Let our every word and deed be done in the name of the Lord Jesus, filled with gratitude for the grace and peace that surpasses all understanding. Amen.
reflection: The question that is often asked, "What is the good life?" 'Is it prosperity, popularity, pleasure?' No, it is the life we receive from Jesus, including gifts that we cannot make or purchase: forgiveness, love, peace, and thankfulness. Jesus' life fills us with virtues rather than vices and enables us to be a blessing rather than a ruin to others. Before the dawning of the final day, let sin's dark deeds be gone!
subject: An Example to Follow
verse_text:
Whatever you do, in word or deed, do everything in the name
of the Lord Jesus, giving thanks to God the Father through
Him.

*Thoughts from Matthew Henry:*



When Matthew Henry was robbed, that very night

he prayed: “I thank Thee, first because I was never

robbed before; second, because although they took

my purse, they did not take my life; third, because

although they took my all, it was not much; and

fourth, because it was I who was robbed, and not I

who robbed.” *Let us practice this type of attitude. *

* Pastor Al*

was never robbed before; second, because although they took
my purse, they did not take my life; third, because although

was I who was robbed, and not I who robbed.” Let us practice
this type of attitude.
original_verse_text:
And we know that all things work together for good to them
that love God, to them who are the called according to his
purpose.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we give thanks that You work all things together for the good of those who love You (Romans 8:28). Help us to learn the secret of being content in any and every situation, for we can do all things through Christ who strengthens us (Philippians 4:11-13). May we have the attitude of Matthew Henry, who recognized Your blessings even in the midst of adversity. Teach us to be grateful, to trust in Your sovereign plan, and to find our sufficiency in You alone. Amen.

Let us practice this type of attitude.
subject: True Gratefulness

that love God, to them who are the called according to his

*From An Embarrassed Waitress: *



A young girl sat at the counter of an ice cream store.

“How much is an ice cream Sunday?” she asked.

“Fifty cents,” the waitress answered with hardly a

glance at the child. The girl opened her fist and counted

her coins. She asked, “how much is a dish of plain ice

cream?” Annoyed, the waitress snapped, “thirty five

cents!” The girl counted out 35 cents and handed it

to the waitress. “I’ll take the plain Ice cream.” The

waitress took the money without a word and brought

the ice cream. After the small customer had eaten and

left, while the waitress was cleaning up, suddenly

became flushed with shame. There, neatly beside the

dish were two nickels and five pennies—her tip.

*What kind of heart do you have? Pastor Al*

After the small customer had eaten and left, while the

original_verse_text:
With all lowliness and meekness, with longsuffering,
forbearing one another in love.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with hearts of humility and compassion. Forgive us for the times when we have been impatient or dismissive towards those in need, like the waitress in the story. Help us to clothe ourselves with kindness, gentleness, and patience, as Your Word instructs in Colossians 3:12. May we treat all people, especially the vulnerable, with the same love and grace that You have shown us through Your Son, Jesus. Give us eyes to see the dignity in every person and the wisdom to respond with empathy and understanding. In Your name we pray, Amen.

*Thought for (11-21-2019)*

Sir Moses Montefiore, the Jewish philanthropist,

had as is motto, “Think and Thank.” In the old

Anglo-Saxon, thankfulness means “thinkfulness.”

Thinking of all God’s goodness draws forth gratitude.

*The question is: Has your attitude brought forth *

*gratitude?*

* Pastor Al *

*Thought for *(11-22-2019)

A mother and her two children were destitute.

In the depth of winter they were nearly frozen,

and so the mother took the cellar door off its

hinges and set it up in front of the corner where

they crouched down to sleep so that some of the

draft and cold might be kept from them. One of

the children whispered to her, “Mother, what

do those do who have no cellar door to put up

in front of them?” *Have you ever thanked God*

*for your many blessings and prayed for those *

*who have less than you?*

* Pastor Al*

Help us to be mindful of the less fortunate and to share Your love and compassion with them. In Your name, we pray. Amen.

*Today's Food for Thought:*

If we were given a dish of sand, and told there were

particles of iron in it, we might look for them with our

clumsy fingers and be *unable* to detect them. But if

we were given a magnet, to sweep through the sand,

it would draw the most invisible particles to itself. The

*thankless* heart is like our clumsy fingers, in the sand,

it discovers no mercies, but let the *thankful heart*

sweep the day, and as the magnet finds the iron, so

the thankful heart will find some heavenly blessings.

*Let us take time once again this Thanksgiving Season, *

*to examine our heart*.

*Pastor Al.*

Like a magnet drawing the invisible particles, may our thankful hearts be swift to recognize the mercies and grace that fill our days. Help us to cultivate a spirit of gratitude, that we may honor You in all we do, and live according to the teachings of Your Son, Jesus Christ. Amen.

*Today’s Food for Thought:* (11-24-2019)

One morning a mother took her three children to a

restaurant for breakfast. The smallest of the three

children sat at the very end of the row. She saw

that other people began eating as soon as they were

served without stopping to give thanks. When the

food was served to her, she shouted out to her mother:

“Mommy, don’t people ask the blessing in this place?”

You can imagine the embarrassment of those present.

Her mother tried to hush her. But the waitress said to

little Mary, “Yes we do, sister! You give thanks!”

Amazingly, at that very moment everybody else also

bowed their heads and offered thanks. *Embarrass them *

*and maybe you* *will bring them to their senses to say, *

*“Thank You God.” *

*Pastor Al*

*Verse for Today: *(11-25-2019)

*Let your roots grow down into Him and draw up*

*nourishment from him, so you will grow in faith, *

*strong and vigorous in the truth you were taught. *

*Let your lives overflow with thanksgiving for all *

*He has done. *(Col. 2:7)



*Thought for Today:*

Paul uses the illustration of our being rooted in Christ.

Just as plants draw their nourishment from the soil

through their roots, so we draw our life-giving strength

from Christ. The more we draw our strength from Him,

the less we will be fooled by those who falsely claim to

have lives answers. *While we are in the season of*

*remembering let us pause to praise and pray giving*

*thanks from our hearts.*

* Pastor Al*

Help us to delight in Your word, meditating on it day and night, that we may be like trees planted by streams of water, bearing fruit in due season. May our lives be a testament to Your goodness, that others may see and know the hope that is found in You alone. We praise You, our Rock and our Redeemer. Amen.

*Today’s Verse:*

*Let the peace that comes from Christ rule in your*

*hearts. For as members of one body you are all*

*called to live in peace. And always be thankful. *

(Col. 3:15)

*Thoughts for Today:*

Gratitude is what always spoils life when it is

left out. A thankful spirit enables one to praise

God even when circumstances are difficult.

Alexander Whyte, a Scottish preacher, always

began his prayers with an expression of gratitude.

One cold, miserable day his people wondered

what he would say. He prayed, “We thank Thee,

O Lord, that it is not always like this.”

*Yes, we always have something to be thankful for.*

……. *Pastor Al*

thankful for.

prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, acknowledging that Your peace and the tranquility it brings surpass all understanding. In the midst of life's challenges, help us to let the peace of Christ rule in our hearts, for it is to this peace that we have been called as members of one body. May our lives be marked by an attitude of thankfulness, for we know that in all things, we have reason to praise Your name. Amen.

*Subject: OBSERVING THANKSGIVING *(11-27-2019)



*Verse for Today: *

“Count it all Joy.” (Jm. 1:2b)



*Thoughts for Today:*

Count your blessings instead of your crosses.

Count your gains instead of your losses.

Count your joys instead of your woes.

Count your friends instead of your foes.

Count your smiles instead of your tears.

Count your courage instead of your fears.

Count your full years instead of your lean.

Count your kind deeds instead of your mean.

Count your health instead of your wealth.

*Count on God instead of yourself, and it will*

*give you much to be thankful for!*

* Pastor Al*

subject   : Subject: THE ART OF THANKSGIVING (11-28-2019)\\\\

*Today’s Verse:*

*Give thanks always for all things to God the Father*

*in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ. *(Eph. 5:20)



*Taking Inventory:*

The art of thanksgiving is, thanks-living. *It is*

gratitude in action.

It is thanking God for, the gift of life *by living*

it triumphantly.

It is thanking God for, your talents and abilities

*by accepting them as*, an obligation to be invested

for the common good.

It is thanking God for, all that men and women *have*

*done for you by*, doing things for others.

It is thanking God for, happiness *by striving* to make

others happy.

It is thanking God for, beauty *by helping* to make the

world more beautiful.

It is thanking God for, inspiration *by trying* to be an

inspiration to others.

It is thanking God for, health and strength *by the *

*care and respect* you show your body.

*Pastor Al*
original_reflection_text:
Taking Inventory: The art of thanksgiving is, thanks-living.
It is gratitude in action. It is thanking God for, the gift
of life by living it triumphantly. It is thanking God for,
your talents and abilities by accepting them as, an
obligation to be invested for the common good. It is
thanking God for, all that men and women have done for you
by, doing things for others. It is thanking God for,
happiness by striving to make others happy. It is thanking
God for, beauty by helping to make the world more beautiful.
It is thanking God for, inspiration by trying to be an
inspiration to others. It is thanking God for, health and
strength by the care and respect you show your body.
original_verse_text:
Give thanks always for all things to God the Father in the
name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, acknowledging that every good and perfect gift comes from You (James 1:17). We thank You for the gift of life, and we commit to living it triumphantly, investing our talents and abilities for the common good. Help us to express our gratitude not just in words, but in actions that bring joy and beauty to the world around us. May our lives be a reflection of Your love and grace, that others may be inspired to know and serve You. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Taking Inventory: The art of thanksgiving is, thanks-living. It is gratitude in action. It is thanking God for the gift of life by living it triumphantly. It is thanking God for your talents and abilities by accepting them as an obligation to be invested for the common good. It is thanking God for all that men and women have done for you by doing things for others. It is thanking God for happiness by striving to make others happy. It is thanking God for beauty by helping to make the world more beautiful. It is thanking God for inspiration by trying to be an inspiration to others. It is thanking God for health and strength by the care and respect you show your body.
subject: The Art of Thanksgiving
verse_text:
Give thanks always for all things to God the Father in the
name of our Lord Jesus Christ.

*Charles Dickens Thoughts:*

Charles Dickens said that we are somewhat

mixed up here in America—he told an audience

that instead of having one Thanksgiving Day

each year we should have 364. “Use that one

day for complaining and griping,” he said. “We

should use the our 364 days to thank God for

His many blessings, He has showered upon us.

*I AGREE WITH THIS IDEA!*

* Pastor Al*

May we give thanks in all circumstances, trusting that Your peace will guard our hearts and minds in Christ Jesus. We praise You for Your unfailing love and faithfulness. Amen.

I AGREE WITH THIS IDEA!

*Verse for Today:*

*Therefore, if any one is in Christ, he is a*

*new creation; the old has gone, the new*

*has come!” *(II Cor. 5:17 NIV)



*Thought for Today:*

Through forgiveness the arms of Jesus

lift you, His blood cleanse you, and His

love changes you. It is His free gift to you.

Turn your heart to Jesus. Pray to receive

Him and His forgiveness by faith today. . .

He will come into your heart and make

all things new. *Do you have the joy of*

*being forgiven? *

* Pastor Al*

original_verse_text: Therefore, if any one is in Christ, he is a new creation; the old has gone, the new has come!
prayer: Heavenly Father, we come before You with grateful hearts, for in Your Son, Jesus, we have been made new. Through His sacrifice, we have been cleansed and forgiven, and by faith, we have been raised to walk in newness of life. Lord, we pray that we may continually turn our hearts to You, that we may experience the joy of Your forgiveness and the transformative power of Your love. May we live as new creations, reflecting Your glory and grace to all we encounter. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: Through forgiveness, the arms of Jesus lift you, His blood cleanses you, and His love changes you. It is His free gift to you. Turn your heart to Jesus. Pray to receive Him and His forgiveness by faith today. He will come into your heart and make all things new. Do you have the joy of being forgiven?
